trial_identification.studytitle: Determining risk factors for surgical wound dehiscence (splitting) after surgery and the development of a surgical wound dehiscence risk tool (SWDRT).
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Retrospective case control study of surgical wound dehiscence and development of a prospectively validated surgical wound dehiscence risk tool (SWDRT).

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Conditions of unknown or disputed aetiology (such as chronic fatigue syndrome/myalgic encephalomyelitis)

interventions.interventions: Historical observational study - case review of community patients over 12 months from Janaury 2010 to January 2011 (Silver Chain data) who have recieved treatment for a surgical wound dehiscence after surgery.
interventions.comparator: Historical - the study will involve a patient case note review from community nursing service (Silver Chain) for treatment over a 12 month period. The study will also involve a case control note review at the matching hospitals where applicable(Royal Perth Hospital, Sir Charles Gardiner Hospital, Fremantle Hospital) for treatment over a 12 month period January 2010 to January 2011.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Variables will be listed as being associated with surgical wound dehiscence. Variables will be subject to statistical analysis to determine the significance of each variable.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: The data to be reviewed would have been collected over a period of one year.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Development of diagnostic tool from the statistical analysis of the variables derived from the case control review.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Twelve months timepoint relative to the period over which the data was collected.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Discharged patients with surgical wound dehiscence
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Pregnant women, patients under 18 years, patients with abdominal compartment syndrome, patients with open abdomen.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The study will be investigating the suspected causes of surgical wound dehiscence and will develop a diagnostic tool to be used in a clinical setting.
